sub_topic: Find the volume form of a given metric.
message_1: Consider the metric given by $ds^2 = 9(dx^2 + dy^2) + 16 dz^2$ on a three dimensional manifold $M$. Find the volume form of this metric on $M$.
message_2:
To find the volume form of the given metric, we first need to find the determinant of the metric tensor. The metric tensor for the given metric is:

$g = \begin{bmatrix}
9 & 0 & 0 \\
0 & 9 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 16
\end{bmatrix}$

The determinant of the metric tensor is:

$|g| = \det(g) = 9 \cdot 9 \cdot 16 = 1296$

Now, the volume form is given by the square root of the absolute value of the determinant of the metric tensor, multiplied by the standard volume form in 3-dimensional Euclidean space:

$\text{vol}(M) = \sqrt{|g|} \, dx \wedge dy \wedge dz = \sqrt{1296} \, dx \wedge dy \wedge dz = 36 \, dx \wedge dy \wedge dz$

So, the volume form of the given metric on the three-dimensional manifold $M$ is:

$\text{vol}(M) = 36 \, dx \wedge dy \wedge dz$
